bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 28, 1939

div1.p: Moran responds to Hench about the article in the Saturday Evening Post by Furnas. Moran makes numerous clarifications about the article and emphasizes the Reed - Finlay controversy. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 28, 1939
div1.opener:
Havana, Aug. 28, 1939.
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean,
U. S. Army, Retired,
Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
1. My sincere thanks for your letter dated August 10th.
It is pleasant news to me that the article by Joseph C. Furnas in the
SATURDAY EVENING POST merits your approval, in general, and that you
find it interesting. I regret that I did not have an opportunity to
correct the errors made by Mr. Furnas. In addition to those mentioned
in your letter, there are a number of others. Where Mr. Furnas should
have named yourself and Major Stark, with Major Reed, as the VIRGINIA
graduates who led me to elect UVA for my couurse in Medicine, he used
Dr. Ames' name instead. At that time, I was on more intimate terms
with Major Stark than I could be with your good self or Major Reed.
I was Dr. Stark's assistant in the operating room and it was from him
I learned that Major Reed and yourself were graduates of UVA. I never
mentioned Dr. Ames to Mr. Furnas as remotely connected with the UVA.
Being from New Orleans, I always imagined that he was a graduate of
Tulane. In preparation for Mr. Furnas' article, I quoted verbatim
from letters you wrote to Prof. Peabody some years ago, very laudatory
of my humble self, when you thought he made little mention of me
while showering praise on Kissinger. Prof. Peabody sent me copies
of your letters in that connection, otherwise I might never have known
of your highly appreciated opinion of me and the part I played in the
yellow fever experiments. As to Mr. Furnas' allegation that Cuba was
free of yellow fever in 1901, when I left Havana, I think he just
imagined it. I told him that I left Cuba on the “Morro Castle”, in
February, 1901, with Major Reed and Kissinger as fellow passengers,
the former returning to Washington and the latter on furlough.

2. When you were fighting yellow fever in Havana in
1905-1906, I was fighting it with Gorgas in Panama. I wanted to
come here with you and wrote to you to that effect. I have never
forgotten your reply. It was to the effect that I “would stand as
much chance as a cat in hell without claws” here, what with the Cuban
politicians trying to place their friends in every worth-while job in
the Sanitary Department. Knowing that your advice to me to remain
where I was, was sound, I made no further effort.

3. On account of the Cubans, I am sorry Mr. Furnas did
not state that Dr. Finlay was born in Cuba, son of a Scotch father and
a French mother. Instead, he made him French-Scotch. So far as I
know, Dr. Finlay did not consider himself a Cuban at the time of the
experiments, anymore than the sons of many Americans resident in Cuba,
engaged in commercial activities, would be considered Cuban citizens
by their parents. By this, I do not mean to cast any reflection on
Cuban citizenship. Americans and Britishers rarely change their
allegiance, especially to become citizens of the Latin-American
republics. Also, Mr. Furnas might have referred to Dr. Agramonte's
immunity to yellow fever in a more happy manner than that employed by him.
You may recall that Dr. Agramonte considered his immunity very doubtful
in his “Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery”, published in the
SCIENTIFIC MONTHLY, in December, 1915, due to the fact that he was
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean. --- 2 --- Aug. 28, 1939.
raised and educated in the U. S., where he was taken by his widowed mother
in early childhood, returning to Cuba only some two or three years after
graduating in Medicine from the College of Physicians & Surgeons, New York.

4. I believe I mentioned in one of my letters to you that
Dr. Philip S. Hench, of the Mayo Clinic, has been accumulating data on
“The Conquest of Yellow Fever” since 1937. His original object was to
publish in one of the accredited medical journals the stories of Kissinger
and Moran, on opposite pages of the same issue. I wrote to him to the
effect that our two accounts of our experience would more than likely
lead to confusion; that the two stories would not dovetail and that one
of us would be contradicting the other, at the same time making it clear
to him that I did not consider myself any more infallible than Kissinger.
I suggested to him, instead, that it would be infinitely more important
to switch his activities to the accumulation of data as to the relative
shares of Reed and Finlay in what we have come to know as “The Conquest
of Yellow Fever”, in an endeavor, once and for all, to impartially set
forth the part played by each.

5. After the passage of forty years, practically, the Cubans
are claiming ALL for Finlay, whose glory, as they claim, has been stolen
by the Americans for Reed. The letter you wrote to me, about the time
the picture “Yellow Jack” was first shown in Cuba, with reference to this
controversy, and which you authorized me to show to anybody interested in
the matter, was read before the Rotary Club here, Dr. Francisco Dominguez
Roldan having been invited to the meeting, and published in “EL MUNDO” and
“Diario de la Marina” the following day. It only served to rile Dr.
Dominguez-Roldan, Finlay's self-appointed champion. Immediately after it
was read, he was called upon to give a little talk to the Rotarians. The
gist of his talk was that FINLAY, AND ONLY FINLAY was entitled to ALL THE
GLORY connected with the conquest of yellow fever; that every claim made
for Reed in marble, bronze, books and The Congressional Record rightfully
belonged to Finlay. On many occasions since, and at every opportunity,
Dr. Dominguez-Roldan charges the Americans with stealing Finlay's glory
for Reed. By this time, most all Cubans, and the medicos without exception,
think Finlay's champion is entirely right. He has won over to his way of
thinking the present generation of Cuban doctors to assure the continued
existence of “The Finlay, and Only Finlay Club”. They look on Agramonte
as a renegade for “The Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery”,
written 15 years after the Reed experiments. To a certain extent, they
had won Agramonte over by the beginning of 1928 when I arrived here from
Mexico. I am quite certain I wrote to you about Agramonte's change of
heart and opinion when I talked to him in 1928-29. He did not know that
I had read his article in the Scientific Monthly.

6. I have suggested to Dr. Hench on more than one occasion
that he write to you in connection with this matter, even suggesting that
you might collaborate with him in such a laudable effort, pointing out to
him that you were one of Major Reed's intimate friends and that your
opinion and knowledge would be sure to be impartial; that you were fam-
iliar with the work of Reed and Finlay, prior to, during and after the
experiments. He expects to come to Havana next March to continue his
investigations and expects from me such assistance as a layman in my
position could be qualified to give. I trust you will not take my in-
terest in this matter to be of the intrusive or meddling variety. I am
very much interested, before I pass on, in having the respective merits
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean. -- 3 -- Aug. 28, 1939.
of Reed and Finlay recorded by an impartial and unprejudiced investigator,
if not in book form, then in an accredited medical journal. I do not think
that any of Reed's family, anymore than those who knew him and appreciated
him during his own lifetime, would wish to rob Finlay of his share of the
glory to which his memory is entitled, in order to glorify Reed. As stated
in your letter dated April 12, 1938, “Ill informed people in the United
States may fail to mention Finlay and ill informed Cubans may fail to
mention Reed, but the fame of each is safe and secure, and I do not worry
over partisan statements”. There is some excuse for the American attitude
with reference to Finlay, but there is very little excuse for the Cuban
attitude with refrence to Reed. The yellow fever epidemic was in Cuba
and Reed's work was done there. For Cubans to deliberately abstain from
even mentioning Reed when they glorify Finlay shows poor sportsmanship on
the part of the Cuban medical fraternity. Not only that, but their in-
direct reference to Reed when they mention “La Comisión Médica Americana”
(The Reed & Carroll Commission) is nothing more nor less than a villification
of his memory. The spirit of intolerance is so manifest to anyone with
even a superficial knowledge of the history of yellow fever as to leave the
unprejudiced observer dumbfounded to discover that the entire medical body
of any nation should be guilty of such narrowmindedness, acting in concert.
Recently, according to data published by Dr. Dominguez-Roldan, it has been
“discovered” that Dr. Finlay actually developed bonafide attacks of yellow
fever, through the mosquito route, with Spanish soldiers and a Spanish
priest as his human guinea pigs. The records of said experiments are said
to have been found in the archives of Dr. Finlay's friend and laboratory
assistant, Dr. Claudio Delgado. Why did not the Cuban medical profession
of Dr. Finlay's day and generation accept his theory and proofs, if they
were so conclusive ? The efforts of the Cuban medical profession to rob
Reed of any glory at all, giving Finlay ALL THE GLORY AND FAME, would
sound childish were it not for the unfortunate fact that its backers are
a scientific body. The Cuban contention will not be allowed to die out,
that you can take for granted. Until after Finlay's death, it was dormant.
Since his death, it has steadily gained impetus and with every passing year
the Cuban champions of Finlay get more and more violent and virulent in
their claims. You know, of course, that Reed's memory to me is something
sacred. I trust you will believe, however, that I am square enough to
give Finlay his due. My own small part in the experiments, let me repeat,
is not involved in any manner in the Reed-Finlay controversey. One thing
is certain and that is that those who know what Reed accomplished are rest-
ing on their oars while those who claim ALL FOR FINLAY are active and venom-
ous. The apparent apathy of the American medical profession in the Reed-
Finlay matter emphasizes the difference between Anglo-Saxons and Latins.
Americans do not so easily froth at the mouth over such matters. There is
always a limit to tolerance, however. To me that limit has been reached
in the Cuban claims for Finlay.

7. We spent a very quiet and physically profitable two weeks
in the Poconos. I gained ten pounds in weight, half of which I lost since
my return to Cuba. I always lose weight in the Summer. Have had no further
trouble with my duodenal ulcer and hope to have it pretty well cured by Xmas.

8. Mrs. Moran joins me in friendliest remembrances to Mrs.
Kean and your very good self. Please let me hear from you when you are in
the mood to write and please pardon me for “wishing” extra trouble on you
in connection with Dr. Hench and his plans.
